summary: Email chain between Assistant United States Attorneys and defense attorney Bruce Barket regarding inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's access to digital discovery materials while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The emails detail scheduling and logistical arrangements for Tartaglione to review evidence and express concerns about access being denied.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney representing inmate Nicholas 'Nick' Tartaglione, raising concerns about his client's lack of access to discovery materials.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Incarcerated individual whose access to digital discovery is being discussed; referred to as 'Nick' and 'Mr. Tartaglione'.

connections.description: Barket is advocating for Tartaglione's access to discovery materials, indicating he is his legal representative.

events.title: Discovery Taken from Tartaglione
events.description: Date referenced by Bruce Barket as when Nicholas Tartaglione's discovery materials were taken from him, after which he allegedly had not been permitted to view them.

events.title: Email Exchange on Discovery Access
events.description: Series of emails discussing and arranging for Nicholas Tartaglione to review his discovery materials over the upcoming weekend and following week at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

locations: Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
New York Metropolitan Correctional Center, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Defense attorney Bruce Barket raised a formal complaint that his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, had not been permitted to view his discovery materials since they were taken from him on October 18, 2019.

The Metropolitan Correctional Center staff outlined a detailed schedule for Tartaglione to review digital discovery, including weekdays in the Education Department and weekends in the attorney conference room.
The email chain reveals logistical challenges and institutional policies governing inmate access to legal materials in a federal correctional facility.

The correspondence involves Assistant United States Attorneys and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the correctional center, indicating the issue was escalated within the legal and prison administration.
